headline: Homemade Corn Dogs
description: Make your own corn dogs using beef frankfurters skewered on sticks, dipped in corn batter, and fried until golden brown for a carnival treat at home.

video.description: See how to make delicious, crunchy corn dogs at home!
video.name: Corn Dogs

name: Homemade Corn Dogs

recipeInstructions.text: Combine cornmeal, flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and pepper in a medium bowl; stir in milk and egg to make a batter.
Heat oil in a deep fryer or large saucepan to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C). Meanwhile, pat frankfurters dry and insert a skewer into each one. Roll frankfurters in batter until well coated.
Fry 2 or 3 corn dogs at a time in preheated oil until lightly browned, about 3 minutes. Drain on paper towels.

review.reviewBody: So easy to make and seriously delicious

First time making corn dogs. Just the two of us, so cut the ingredients by half. The first four we beef sausage links. Came out great. The second group of four we Nathan's hot dogs. Also excellent. Simple recipe, very tasty. Sorry there are only six in the photo (we were very hungry) ;-)

These came out so good üëçüèΩ. Will definitely make again. So easy! I only made them cause my granddaughter wanted them and I refused to buy those over-priced nasty tasteless things from the store. I had leftover batter and fried it up and made critters; also tasty. I ate mine with brown mustard; granddaughter used ketchup. THANK YOU!! üëèüèΩü¶ãüíú

the batter was tasteless. needs to be spiced up. mine stayed on the dogs because i followed another's suggestion to flour them up. i thinned the batter after reading some reviews--that was a mistake. the kids don't want them again. great suggestion to pour into a pint glass--made the coating part easy!
Delicious, thank you for this!!üòÅ
I love ti food
Wonderful for corndogs and I add jalape√±os and grateful onions to make them into hush puppies. So so great!
Great recipe. Definitely need to have a a deep vessel to fry the dogs as they tend to float to the top. I cooked two at a time and they were perfectly corny, sweet, crunchy yet soft on the outside.
This was an amazing recipe highly recommend it to someone who wants to make corn dogs for themselves we didn‚Äôt use regular Frank‚Äôs we used cheddar sausages so good
I made these with vegan hot dogs. They were too fat and sunk to the bottom. Very heavy. Next time I‚Äôll probably cut the dog lengthwise. Easy recipe though. All ingredients readily on hand.
I just made this but I didn't have corn flour so instead I used almond flour and it turned out soooooooooo good

Wonderful recipe! The corn dogs turned out big, fluffy and delicious. I don't know if it makes a big difference but I fried in corn oil....suppose it's a matter of taste. I also omitted a tsp of the sugar.
In South Africa corn meal is known as Mealie Meal‚Ä¶ no yellow , but the local white meal works just as well. I used Almond milk instead of dairy milk to make it Kosher. Perfect and tasty
Horrible, much better recipes than this out there. Gritty, thick and horrible batter.
Great recipe as is! Made amazing mini corn dogs!
This recipe is awesome! I will definitely be making these again. My only criticism (and it is a small one) The batter is a little heavy on the corn meal. I will cut that down a bit next time.
Amazing they taste so good I highly recommend this recipe.
The dough is perfect. Tender and delicious! I would recommend a bit less sugar and no pepper.

They're pretty good! It was my first time making corn dogs and I will make them again, but next time I may try adding seasoning to the batter as I did find them a little flat. Quick and very easy to make!
I hope they freeze well.
I LOVE this recipe, as did the rest of my family. It's simple and easy. I double dipped mine though, and only used 1 pack of hot dogs.
Really good. Used buttermilk instead of regular milk just because I prefer my cornbread that way. Turned out really great. Crispy outside and soft and fluffy inside.
A nice crunch. A personal preference to use less sugar next time.
Awesome and yummy
I used a bagel instead of breading. It was bad. Do not recommend this recipe, but i LOVE the peppermint.

They are amazing, just had trouble dipping the corn dogs, they either had thick amount of batter or i
I was missing batter.

Whoa, these are dangerously good. My 7-year-old requested corn dogs for his birthday and I figured I'd try it even though I've never deep fried anything before. I thought a couple kids would eat them, but then all the adults ended up eating one and wishing there were more. The only change I made was to reduce the sugar. That makes them healthy corn dogs. As other reviewers suggested, I dried the hot dogs well before dipping in the batter. The batter layer does not need to go on thick.

I had no idea how to actually fry anything, and the recipe doesn't cover that, so if you need tips: 
- I used a 1.5 qt bottle of canola oil in a cast iron dutch oven
- I kept the oil at 350-375 degrees and made sure it was correct before each batch
- The whole corn dog floated sideways in the oil, and I rotated it periodically. 
- I was able to put in 2-3 corn dogs at a time
- They took 2-4 minutes each (I didn't actually time it), and it's easy to tell when you should take them out because they turn a beautiful golden brown color

It couldn't be easier, and it was a delicious treat!
Perfect

Was missing the county fair this year so this hit the spot! I omitted the pepper and mixed it in a mason jar so was able to dip the hot dogs in. I made mini corn dogs and they were awesome. Thank you to the reviewers who said to make sure the batter is cold, the hot dogs are dry and to use a glass‚Äîthose were ace suggestions. I am beyond happy!

Sooo delicious! We all loved them and the kids were soo fascinated that we were making our own. They turned out great! I patted the hotdogs dry, mixed batter and poured batter into a tall glass to dip. They were perfect golden brown and so light and fluffy inside. Definitely adding this to our rotation!

too sweet and not so crunchy
i suggest but the batter in fridge for 30 min
and dust the hotdog with flower before soaking in the batter 
also reduce one table spoon of suger from the ingredients
This recipe is spot on. I made corn dogs for a Carnival movie night and everyone loved them. There wasn‚Äôt a single complaint. It was so simple to make I will never buy frozen corn dogs again.

I used buttermilk instead of milk, had locally grown pink cornmeal (but it will turn golden so don‚Äôt worry about color), and omitted the pepper. 

I did find there is a way to twist and push in and pull back out, to cover the dog, and that it needs to be placed in boiling oil immediately...hold near bottom a few seconds before dropping in. (Yes I listened to the ex carnie and patted each dog dry before dipping.)

I used real lard for cooking. Instead of full wieners I cut in half (natural Oscar Meyer beef) and placed on long metal BBQ skewers meant for shish-kabobs. Then I pushed the dog off the skewer with a table knife. I left until brown and then put onto plate with paper towel, but it might be even wiser to put onto a cookie rack to cool to eliminate dampness created. 

The results were tasty (no you do not need to precook) and it reminded me of the mini corn dogs frozen in grocery stores. 

However, I did chill the batter and it became too thick, so I had to add more buttermilk and stir. The batter coated it, but it was a thin coating not thick. It tastes fine by me, but I give it 4 stars because it is not thick.
Absolutely easy and delicious no dripping had to add and bit more of the liquid was to thick over all put in mason jar and let chill get Distance he worth making will make it again

Good recipe, it was a little too salty and I usually omit a portion of sugar(my standard) We refrigerated the mix and added about a quarter cup more milk. In addition dried the hotdogs really well. We though the outcome was great.

It was great! I'm not sure how this recipe would cover 2lbs of hot dogs unless they were small hot dogs. As it was, we used Kirkland Signature all-beef dogs and we had one naked dog at the end. It's possible the mix was too thick too, but I don't know how to tell since I've never done it before! LOL Next time I might try adding a touch more milk.

I didn't see it mentioned, but the temperature should be between 350 and 375.

I tried the flour trick on some of them just to see how it worked and dried dogs worked way better. And keeping the batter cold, as someone suggested, really helped it stick to the dogs too. 

The cup method worked really well but after the first four dogs, there wasn't enough left in the cup to cover the dogs so I ended up spooning the batter over them.

My kids loved it and ate more than they usually would! Thanks!

Made mini turkey dogs, tempeh dogs and beyond burger dogs with this batter. DELICIOUS! Drying the meats (and meat substitutes) then rolling them in corn starch is your best bet to make sure the batter stays. I even fried them in a saucepan but that pre frying treatment made sure I didn‚Äôt have triangle dogs
Batter was excellent! I didn't make them quite as crispy as i would have liked but ill cook a lil longer next time.

I made these for the first time and followed the recipe to a T. I thought the batter was too thick but decided to go with it. So glad I did as it made the perfect coating for the dogs. I shook off a bit of the excess and they fried up beautifully. Golden brown and perfectly toast inside. Also, I fried them without the sticks as I didn't have a ton of oil so they fried in a saucepan on their sides. They turned out perfect and I skewered them when they came out of the oil. This recipe is a keeper.

Good recipe next time I'd half the sugar and omit the pepper though. make sure dogs are dry and batter will stick, as another reviewer suggested the colder the batter the less dripping! Tall drinking glass definitly the easier way to dunk dogs in batter

It's a decent recipe, but so much work to get something you can buy so cheaply for almost the same effect. Homemade in this case is not a lot better than store bought. Just not worth the time and energy
I followed the recipe exactly, minus the pepper. It turn out great and the kids devoured it!
Yuck! It is sweet. Won‚Äôt make it again.

i will make this over and over again, even my dad likes them (even though he doesn't admit it)! although i still haven't figured out what to do with the oil when i'm done so i just use it over and over again.
-karmann
Very good

Incredible!! Followed the recipe exactly but took the advice of the reviewer who said to chill the mix (had to add more milk when we took it out), and wiped off the hot dogs. Batter stayed on perfectly and they were absolutely amazing. As good as at the carnival!
So yummy! And very easy to make :) I would maybe coat the frankfurters with flour before coating so that more can stay on the sausage.

I used soy milk instead of regular milk and veggie dogs cause I don't eat meat and they turned out great! They were sooo delicious ?? I made 16 so I can freeze them for easy meals! Definitely be making them again. I might add a little maple syrup or honey next time I make them for an added flavor
This was REALLY good! As per one of the reviewers I made hush puppies with left over batter. Will make again! Thank you, SUZZANNA!

I made these just as written with the suggestions from the carney to dry the dogs and chill the cornbread batter and they came out perfect! I didn't have any issues with the batter falling off. I used fine ground corn meal (not course). I might reduce the amount of milk a little and add a bit of seasoning to the batter next time, but fantastic regardless! Thanks for sharing!
Make sure to coat your dogs in flour before dipping into batter. Other than that, they tasted great! I will make these again!
Had all the ingredients!! It was simple and delicious!!
tasty. Many thanks for the great recipe. Greetings from Germany
This is the second time I've used this recipe. The second time I used corn flour instead of corn grits. The dogs were a lot better.

I made these with the ingredients listed in the correct measurements, but did NOT use all beef hotdogs, and used two 8 packs of dogs cut in half-no sticks. I put the dough in the freezer while I cut my hotdogs (which went into the fridge as soon as they were cut), and made my chips-I am submitting a photo as well for you to see. I used a fondue fork to lift them out of the vegetable oil, and held them up and turned them a bit and lightly tapped the fork on the side of the bowl to coat them all over and remove excess--you do not need a lot of batter on there to make beautiful corn dogs! Even small bare patches were covered when removed from the oil because the breading expands enough to do that. I made little bread balls with the left over batter- me and my 4 yo granddaughter were the only one's who loved the dough alone. Will be making these again and am testing them for freezing and re-cooking so that I can have them when I am working in the summer. Will try to contact the OP if I am successful in freezing (or will leave a comment here to let users know how it works out.) Good recipe if you follow fundamental cooking rules and techniques. Thank you for sharing it here.
love it
Corn dogs are a real comfort food for me and these were perfect. Thanks
This was so much fun and easy to do. The kids loved it. We substituted the hot dogs with small sausage links and used a deep fryer for ease. They came out great and truly recommend!
these were DELICIOUS! I had to double the milk because the batter was extremely thick, but once I did that they were perfect. 100% will be making again!

I didn't have any cornmeal so I substituted with breadcrumbs and it turned out just as amazing! Also if you have left over batter, drop spoonfuls into the oil and fry up just the dough for a yummy snack!
I was really high and hungry for a corn dog. thanks you !
We loved the corn dog batter, will be making this again!
I made them with smoked sausages and they were amazing!
Delish! Enjoyed this recipe to the fullest. Thank you.

I chilled the batter in the fridge. It puffed up and got very dry so I had to add a bit more milk and stir it up. I dried off the hotdogs and cooked at 365 degrees as suggested by another reviewer. I cut the hot dogs in half and cut skewers in half. They fit in a small pot to deep-fry. Yummers.
I made this. We dont eat beef so we eat turkey dogs so finding a great corndog receipe was so great. It was easy and did not take long at all to cook and they came out great!

I followed the advice to dry the hot dogs and chill the batter. They were perfect, as long as i kept the oil around 365 degrees (as recommended in the video). Otherwise the outside got really dark, but the hot dog never warmed through. Easily the best corn dogs of my life.
I would recommend this recipe. I read the reviews and followed the tips, and they came out great! Most definitely will be making these again.
No! Their perfect the way their are.

This recipe was AMAZING! I used Lil Smokies with the batter to make appetizers for the Seahawks game and they were a huge hit! I dried the meat thoroughly first and the batter stuck fine. I didn‚Äôt put the smokies in right away so the batter started to puff up but, it didn‚Äôt matter. Even though there might have been a couple of small bare spots when I dropped them in the oil, the batter puffs up so beautifully that every piece was completely covered when they were done. The texture was light and soft on the inside with just the right amount of crunch on the outside. I‚Äôll definitely use this recipe again. Thanks!
These are amazing. You can‚Äôt go wrong here

It was wonderful! Everyone said they loved it and gave it the ‚ÄúGood for Vacation‚Äù award.
I was not too hard, the frying part was a bit lengthy.
From some of the pictures you can see I didn‚Äôt really use the sticks because we didn‚Äôt have any, so instead I used skewers for dipping then took it off for frying so that the pan didn‚Äôt have to be so tall. 
The second time I made it we were going to be gone all day so I wrapped each on in plastic wrap then froze them. It made it so much easier to make. And if we don‚Äôt use them all we can save them for next time!
These were so simple and easy to make- and absolutely delicious!
Was better than any I have ever had
i followed directions as told to a T. and i had the cornmeal mixture in frig to chill. and hot dogs dry but the batter would not stick no matter... just wasnt gonna stick... will NOT try again...

I used buttermilk and used a tip I was given, to make sure the batter is cold. I think I'd add a little more milk and not chill the batter, it made it really thick and somewhat hard to evenly cook the batter on the dog.
This is an amazing and simple recipe! A family favorite!
My sons loved these! Very easy to make with not a lot to clean up. Next time I'll cut the sugar in half though.

Took me 3 times to finally get right. I recommend letting batter refrigerate for 20 to 30 min to let it thicken. Also use spoon to spread batter lightly using lesser because the more batter you use it makes it harder to stay onto dogs.
I made a batch for my wife and I. She is not a corn dog fan, but she loved the batter for this recipe!
This was a huge hit with my family! My kids love corn dogs and we will always make them this way now!

I really wish I would have read the reviews first, some good tips in there. I had no cornmeal (what is a corn dog without cornmeal? desperation maybe), so I used extra flour instead which resulted in a lot more milk being needed to make the batter, well, batter. And I rolled the hot dogs in flour first so the batter would stay on. Can‚Äôt wait to try it again with actual cornmeal because it‚Äôs so good!
recipe was perfect, I used cheddar sausage dogs. The next time, I'm going to add jalapenos. We'll love them even more.
I've tried several recipes from you tube and pinterest and this one is the easiest and best. Added honey to the batter. Kid approved!
All the batter came off almost instantly.
Yes I'll make it again
Outstanding recipe ! Tastes so yummy ! Just make sure your oil is not too hot ! My dogs got a little too dark but were very good anyway !

these turned out great ! easier then I expected. i boiled the hot dogs before battering them and putting in the oil. When I put my first corndog in I realized the oil was not hot enough so I just took it out and re-battered and it turned out great still. Oil temperature is everything for this recipe ! Also I did not use pepper as other reviews suggested.
I used organic cornmeal and organic chicken hot dogs. I only had a package of 6 hotdogs but this recipe probably could have made double that because I had a lot of leftover batter.
I did not deep fry, I baked them in a sandwich maker. Yes I will make it again

If you are frying them in a fry pan be sure to flip them to the other side soon after putting it in the oil. The batter fries quickly. The hot dog didn‚Äôt even have time to warm up before the batter was dark brown. They tasted ok, but I think I will stick with the freezer corn dogs.

Coating didn't stick too well to the hotdogs.. even when I dried the hotdog off first. Wanted to try something other than freezer to microwave.. this one kinda missed the mark. Will try a different one next time
Great recipe! Use Pork dogs instead of Beef. The Pork compliments the Cornmeal. I used the advise from the "Carnie".....thank you !

Had to use an extra half cup of flower for the mix to get the right consistency

And they were delicious
First time making corn dogs . This recipe was delicious. I didn‚Äôt make any adjustments to it. My 8 yr old loved it.

These are awesome, followed the recipe less the black pepper. Be careful though. If your grease is too hot, the outer part will cook quickly while the inside remains gooey. I used medium low heat and didn't rush. Beautiful and tasty.
I had trouble cooking all the way through, and it was a little too sweet for me. Otherwise, really good

These were really good. I followed the recipe with no changes and my family loved them. I made sure to dry my hot dogs really well and let them sit out on a paper towel while the oil heated and I prepared the batter. My only small complaint is that I wish the breading was a little thicker around the dog (it‚Äôs my favorite part), so I‚Äôll try again and see if I can use a little less milk in the batter or something. The taste was on point though! I used the Nathan‚Äôs bun length dogs.

Thank you so much for this recipe, I made it for my family and they enjoyed it so much that they wanted more that very day. Here a lot of the frankfurters are salty so adding this bread like coating really cut down the sodium. I thought it was just a little to sweet for me so next time I am going to reduce the amount of sugar. But thank you so much for the recipe!
It was very good! I made it like octopi dressed as ghosts and used an edible marker to make faces. Everyone loved it!
Made these tonite and we were impressed! They tasted exactly like a legit corn dog :) used cheap wieners and cut them in half both ways. Ate them with our fingers. Will make again!

item.name: Hot Dogs and Corn Dogs Recipes
